    "Step 2: Estimated market caps using public market-cap aggregators (CompaniesMarketCap pages per company) and assigned Tier 1 to more de-risked, strategically adjacent, commercial/late-stage assets with broader acquirer fit; assigned Tier 2 to earlier-stage or more execution-dependent platform plays with meaningful strategic value but lower near-term certainty."

tier_1_targets.name: Intra-Cellular Therapies, Inc.
tier_1_targets.strategic_rationale: CNS-focused commercial-stage asset (CAPLYTA) with expanding label potential; attractive bolt-on for large pharma seeking near-term revenue plus differentiated psychiatry franchise and lifecycle management upside.

tier_1_targets.name: Sarepta Therapeutics, Inc.
tier_1_targets.strategic_rationale: Rare disease leader in Duchenne muscular dystrophy with commercial base and gene therapy platform; strategic fit for acquirers building neuromuscular + genetic medicines franchises and seeking scale in specialty rare disease commercialization.

tier_1_targets.name: Alnylam Pharmaceuticals, Inc.
tier_1_targets.strategic_rationale: Best-in-class RNAi platform with multiple marketed products and broad pipeline; compelling for large pharma to secure durable gene-silencing modality leadership, expand rare/cardiometabolic footprint, and leverage global commercial infrastructure.

tier_1_targets.name: BioMarin Pharmaceutical Inc.
tier_1_targets.strategic_rationale: Scaled rare disease commercial portfolio with strong cash generation and deep expertise in orphan drug development; attractive for acquirers seeking de-risked revenue, durable pricing power, and pipeline optionality in genetic diseases.

tier_1_targets.name: Ionis Pharmaceuticals, Inc.
tier_1_targets.strategic_rationale: Antisense oligonucleotide (ASO) platform with partnered economics and late-stage assets; strategic for acquirers wanting nucleic-acid therapeutics breadth (ASO alongside RNAi/mRNA), plus pipeline leverage and IP moat.

tier_2_targets.name: Arcellx, Inc.
tier_2_targets.strategic_rationale: Differentiated cell therapy platform (D-Domain) and BCMA CAR-T program; attractive to oncology-focused acquirers seeking next-gen CAR-T differentiation, improved safety/efficacy profile, and manufacturing/CMC know-how.

tier_2_targets.name: Krystal Biotech, Inc.
tier_2_targets.strategic_rationale: Commercial gene therapy in dermatology with platform potential for additional skin indications; strategic for acquirers building gene therapy + rare dermatology franchises with near-term revenue and lifecycle expansion opportunities.

tier_2_targets.name: Beam Therapeutics Inc.
tier_2_targets.strategic_rationale: Base editing platform with multiple programs; strategic for acquirers seeking next-generation genome editing beyond CRISPR nucleases, with potential for improved precision and broader therapeutic window across hematology and liver targets.

tier_2_targets.name: Recursion Pharmaceuticals, Inc.
tier_2_targets.strategic_rationale: AI/ML-enabled drug discovery and large-scale phenomics platform; strategic for acquirers aiming to internalize computational discovery capabilities, expand target ID/lead optimization throughput, and complement existing R&D engines.

tier_2_targets.name: Viking Therapeutics, Inc.
tier_2_targets.strategic_rationale: Metabolic disease pipeline (notably obesity/NASH-related mechanisms) with high strategic value for cardiometabolic portfolios; attractive to acquirers seeking differentiated incretin-adjacent or complementary assets and commercial scale in obesity.

parsed_response.selection_methodology: Screened U.S.-listed biotech companies for (i) strategic relevance to large-cap pharma/biopharma acquirers (rare disease, oncology/cell therapy, CNS, cardiometabolic, genetic medicines, and enabling platforms), (ii) presence of commercial or late-stage assets and/or differentiated platforms with clear portfolio adjacency, (iii) market caps generally within a feasible acquisition range for large acquirers, and (iv) business models where full ownership could unlock value (global commercialization, lifecycle management, platform leverage). Tiering reflects relative plausibility based on maturity (commercial/late-stage vs earlier), breadth of strategic fit, and typical acquirer appetite for de-risked cash flows versus platform optionality.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Screened U.S.-listed biotech universe for companies with differentiated modalities/platforms (RNAi/ASO, gene therapy, genome editing, CAR-T, AI discovery) or scaled commercial rare disease/CNS/cardiometabolic franchises that are commonly targeted by large pharma for growth and pipeline replenishment.

Step 2: Estimated market caps using public market-cap aggregators (CompaniesMarketCap pages per company) and assigned Tier 1 to more de-risked, strategically adjacent, commercial/late-stage assets with broader acquirer fit; assigned Tier 2 to earlier-stage or more execution-dependent platform plays with meaningful strategic value but lower near-term certainty.
